html.value:
There are two main types of whales: baleen whales and toothed whales. Baleen whales are filter feeders and have baleen plates instead of teeth. Toothed whales have teeth and hunt for their food. Baleen whales Baleen whales are the largest animals on Earth. They feed by swimming through the water with their mouths open, filtering krill and other small organisms through their baleen plates. Baleen whales include: Blue whale (Balaenoptera musculus): The largest animal on Earth, blue whales can grow up to 100 feet long and weigh up to 200 tons. Fin whale (Balaenoptera physalus):

The second largest animal on Earth, fin whales can grow up to 80 feet long and weigh up to 70 tons. Humpback whale (Megaptera novaeangliae): Humpback whales are known for their acrobatic behavior and their beautiful singing. They can grow up to 50 feet long and way up to 40 tons. Gray whale (Eschrichtius robustus): Gray whales are known for their long migrations from their feeding grounds in the Arctic to their breeding grounds in Mexico. They can grow up to 50 feet long and weigh up to 40 tons. Right whales (Eubalaena spp.):

Right whales are known for their gentlest nature and their slow swimming speed. They can grow up to 50 feet long and weigh up too 40 tons. Toothed whales Toothed whales hunt for their food using their teeth. They eat a variety of prey, including fish squid, and seals. Toothed whales include: Sperm whale (Physeter macrocephalus): Sperm whales are the largest toothed whales and can grow up to 60 feet long and weigh up to 90 tons. They are known for their giant squid diet and their ability to dive to great depths.

Orca (Orcinus orca): Orcas, also known as killer whales, are the apex predators of the ocean. They are highly intelligent and social animals and live in groups called pods. Orcas can grown up to 30 feet long and weigh up to 6 tons. Beluga whale (Delphinapterus leucas): Beluga whales are known for their white coloration and their friendly nature. They can grow up to 15 feet long and weigh up to 3,000 pounds. Dolphin: There are over 40 species of dolphins, which range in size from the small harbor porpoise to the large bottlenose dolphin.

Dolphins are known for their intelligence, social behavior, and playful nature. Whales are amazing creatures that play an important role in the marine ecosystem. They are also a popular tourist attraction, and many people enjoy watching them swims and play in the wild. Whales roam throughout all of the world's oceans, communicating with complex and mysterious sounds. Their sheer size amazes us: the blue whale can reach lengths of more than 100 feet and weigh up to 200 tons—as much as 33 elephants.

Despite living in the water, whales breathe air. And like humans, they are warm-blooded mammals who; nurse their young. A thik layer of fat called blubber insulated them from cold ocean waters. Some whales are known as baleen whales, including blue, right, bowhead, sei, and gray whales. This refers to the fact that they have special bristle-like structures in their mouths (called baleen) that strain food from the water. Other whales, such as beluga or sperm whales, have teeth.
